issue.title: Take stock of all algorithms
issue.body:
This issue to capture what we discussed today (also for the benefit of @christianpaquin): 

- Create a current view as to where we stand for each algorithm (round3 readiness, code level, etc.)
- Decide whether/how to parcel out work to arrive at 0.5 release readiness (incl. whether/how to address common code issues as per #849).
- Probably also list release-criteria for 0.5 (not discussed today but in a previous meeting).

@dstebila @xvzcf are working on this.

comment.body:
> Question(s) on FrodoKEM: Is that really complete/correct?
> 
> 1. Shouldn't this read "SHA3":
> 
> https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/bac7c59d5add68018dc5393229503ce7d68af51c/docs/algorithms/kem/frodokem.yml#L44

You're right, fixed; thanks.

> 1. Should these URLs be filled-in (or removed):
>    https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/bac7c59d5add68018dc5393229503ce7d68af51c/docs/algorithms/kem/frodokem.yml#L22-L24

That's just so you all can see the syntax, will be removed for Frodo eventually since Frodo doesn't need them.

> Finally, am I assuming correct that we don't explicitly/separately list reference implementation(s) -- unless no optimized variant is available?

Yes.

comment.body:
> Additional question regarding secret dependent branching: Do I assume correct that we shall state `false` on `no-secret-dependent-branching-claimed` if we have a suppression file ([e.g., for HQC](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/constant_time/kem/issues/hqc_fast_convolution_mult)) -- as well as `true` on `no-secret-dependent-branching-checked-by-valgrind`?
> 
> One could argue that the claim to this property is made by the authors, though, as the NIST submission states "Our optimized AVX2 implementation is now constant time and avoids secret dependent memory access" (in my eyes code branches _are_ --code-- memory accesses). Given this, these bits now confuse me a bit: Could @xvzcf @jschanck @dstebila please provide guidance/a link as to how to set these truth values?

I'd say we should put a link to the suppression file indicating the exceptions.

comment.body:
> I'd say we should put a link to the suppression file indicating the exceptions.

How/where? Also, please note that in the case of HQC it's 3 files. Until that's clear, I'll consider HQC done: Please take a look. If you'd want me to extend the YAML->MD converter, please let me know where that code is (@xvzcf ? Didn't find it in `scripts` or `doc`).

issue.title: Java Provider
issue.body: I'd like to implement the use of this openssl version with Java however I can't find the provider required to consume it in java. If this is already implemented I'd love to be pointed at it, if not its an extremely important library that must be built for widespread adoption.

comment.body:
I have been down the rabbit hole too! Combined with the code base provided by the product team it's tough determining the best place to perform 'OQS surgery' as I'm starting to call it.

The IP owners make it extremely difficult here, but we are definitely starting with a proof of concept. I do have control of both client and server for the app. Thanks for your offer of assistance. Where is the best place to discuss further?

issue.title: Java Provider
issue.body: I'd like to implement the use of this openssl version with Java however I can't find the provider required to consume it in java. If this is already implemented I'd love to be pointed at it, if not its an extremely important library that must be built for widespread adoption.

comment.body:
> Where is the best place to discuss further?

As this is a "demos"/POC question, what about [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/issues/79)?

issue.title: No documentation available to easily cross compile a library for Windows
issue.body:
I wanted to compile a liboqs library for windows using linux and I was unable to find a way to do it just following the documentation. We should have a section in readme specifying how to properly cross compile. For example

## Cross compiling LIBOQS from Ubuntu to Windows
To build a `.dll` file

```bash
sudo apt install cmake gcc gcc-mingw-w64 ninja-install
git clone https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs
cd liboqs
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../.CMake/toolchain_windows-amd64.cmake -DOQS_DIST_BUILD=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON ..
ninja
```

The result of ninja process, will generate a `bin/liboqs.dll` file on project root directory

comment.body:
@zerjioang Thanks for the suggestion. When I run your suggestion to build a DLL above, I encounter some issues:
- `ninja-install` doesn't seem to be an ubuntu-installable APT package; only `ninja-build` works for me
- After running `ninja`, I only seem to be getting a file `liboqs.dll.a` which subsequently cannot be executed on Windows.

--> Could you please update your description as to what needs to be done to arrive at a Windows-executable DLL? Would you want to do that as part of a PR to update [README.md](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/README.md)? Are you using this DLL to handle https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python/issues/36 (i.e., are cross-building the Windows-DLL for the python wrapper and not build it on Windows natively)? May this explain the naming issue there?

comment.body: Regarding HQC: How about I open an issue describing the non-constant time behaviour that is documented in the suppression files, and then we link to the issue.
